Award.AwardTitle: Imaging the Outskirts of Nearby Disk Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Precisely how galaxies initially form and how they change throughout their lifetime are among the least understood problems in astrophysics. Many projects are centered on unraveling these mysteries. This project relies on the outskirts of galaxy disks to provide clues about the dynamical evolution of their host galaxy. In galaxy outskirts are preserved the dynamical signatures of past accretions and evolutionary processes such as radial migration, accretion, star formation thresholds, and low level in situ star formation. The principal investigator plans to obtain deep, wide-field images of nearby disk galaxies within 4--10 Mpc to study the structure, stellar populations, and star forming properties of their outer disks. The combination of the investigators' experience with deep, very low surface brightness measurements and the unique telescope/detector instrumentation are ideally suited toward this project. The primary scientific motivations are (1) to determine the structure of extended galaxy disks, (2) to determine how much star formation has contributed to the growth of outer disks, (3) to determine how accretion shaped nearby galaxies, and (4) to determine how surface photometry and discrete star counts compare in their ability to probe the outskirts of galaxies.

Educationally, this project will provide opportunities for beginning students to get hands-on research observatory experience---as an observer and as an instrumentalist. Such training is critical for students and for an astronomical community that needs technically-trained scientists. The principal investigator will continue his excellent history of providing his imaging and simulations to planetarium shows and to public outreach web sites, and he will give public talks at local astronomy clubs and the Cleveland Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on deep imaging of nearby galaxies to study the
structure, morphology, and colors of their very faint outer regions.
These regions hold clues to the formation and evolution of galaxies.
We focused on spiral galaxies like our own Milky Way galaxy, as well
as interacting galaxies and those in dense galaxy clusters. We showed
that many spiral galaxies have red and smooth outer disks, indicating
old stars that are well mixed in space, with little evidence for
recent star formation. Galaxies like this likely grow their outer
disks by a process called "radial migration", where stars in the inner
parts of the galaxy gradually move outwards over time when they
interact gravitationally with the galaxies' spiral arms.

We also found a striking counter-examples of a spiral galaxy with a
blue outer disk -- the nearby Pinwheel Galaxy, M101. The outer disk
was extremely faint and blue, suggestive of young stars formed in a
weak burst of star formation several hundred million years ago (our
follow-up study with the Hubble Space Telescope has now confirmed this
result). The ages of these young stars is approximately equal to the
timescale for a recent interaction with one of M101's companion
galaxies, and we used deep radio imaging of the galaxy to show
evidence of the interaction in the galaxies' gaseous components as
well.

We also imaged two galaxies in a specific wavelength of light selected
to show ionized gas clouds that trace young star formation. This
imaging improved on previous work by detecting fainter star forming
regions as well as surveying the galaxies' surrounding
environments. Our imaging shows that star formation in M101 extends
very far out into the outer disk, where young stars continue to form
today. In another interacting galaxy, the Whirlpool (M51), we detect
little star formation in its long tidal tail, showing that not all
galaxy collisions trigger extended star formation. We also discovered
a vast plume of ionized gas near the system, possibly left over from
when the galaxy pair first collided several hundred million years
ago. Followup studies are planned for this plume of ionized gas, which
could constrain the collision timescale for the galaxy pair.

Finally, the project provided critical technical training in data
analysis and observatory science for one graduate student and four
undergraduate students. The project resulted in 7 refereed
publications, and 10 conference presentations about our work. We are
releasing the data publicly so other astronomers can utilize it. We
also gave a number of public talks about the research to audiences in
museums, community groups, and schools.
